en: He sat back. A sense of complete helplessness had descended upon him. To begin with, he did not know with any certainty that this was 1984. It must be round about that date, since he was fairly sure that his age was thirty-nine, and he believed that he had been born in 1944 or 1945; but it was never possible nowadays to pin down any date within a year or two.
vi: Anh khẽ ngả người ra sau. Cảm giác bất lực bao trùm khắp cơ thể. Trước hết anh không biết năm nay có đúng là năm 1984 hay không. Không nghi ngờ gì rằng con số gần đúng như thế vì anh biết chắc tuổi của mình là ba chín, mà anh sinh khoảng năm 1944 hay 1945, nhưng bây giờ thì chẳng có cách nào xác định được chính xác, sai số phải khoảng một hai năm.
tr: Geriye yaslandı. Kendini tümden çaresiz hissetti. Her şeyden önce, yılın 1984 olduğundan emin değildi. Yaşı, tam otuz dokuz olduğuna göre, yıl 1984 olmalıydı. 1944 ya da 1945 yılında doğduğunu sanıyordu, ama bir ya da iki yılın içindeki kesin tarihleri saptamak olanaksızdı artık.
es: Se echó hacia atrás en la silla. Estaba absolutamente desconcertado. Lo primero que no sabía con certeza era si aquel era, de verdad, el año 1984.
vi_translation: He gently leaned back. A feeling of helplessness enveloped his entire body. First of all, he didn't know if this year was really 1984. There was no doubt that the number was approximately correct because he was certain that he was thirty-nine years old, and he was born around 1944 or 1945, but now there was no way to determine the exact year, with an error margin of about one or two years.
tr_translation: He leaned back. He felt utterly helpless. Above all, he was not sure that the year was 1984. Since he was exactly thirty-nine years old, the year should be 1984. He thought he was born in 1944 or 1945, but it was now impossible to determine the exact dates within a year or two.
es_translation: He leaned back in the chair. He was absolutely bewildered. The first thing he was not sure about was whether it was really the year 1984. Of course, the date had to be approximately that, since he had been born in 1944 or 1945, he believed; but, "who knows what year it is today!"

en: Suddenly he began writing in sheer panic, only imperfectly aware of what he was setting down. His small but childish handwriting straggled up and down the page, shedding first its capital letters and finally even its full stops:
vi: Rồi bất ngờ anh viết - đơn giản là do sợ, anh cũng không biết mình viết gì nữa. Anh viết những hàng chữ khi lên khi xuống như trẻ con, lúc đầu quên viết hoa rồi sau quên luôn cả đánh dấu chấm câu.
tr: Birden, panik içinde yazmaya başladı, neler karaladığının pek farkında değildi. Küçük, çocuksu el yazısı, sayfa üzerinde dolaşıyor, önce büyük harflerden, sonra noktalardan vazgeçiyordu.
es: De repente, empezó a escribir con gran rapidez, como si lo impulsara el pánico, dándose apenas cuenta de lo que escribía. Con su letrita infantil iba trazando líneas torcidas y si primero empezó a «comerse» las mayúsculas, luego suprimió incluso los puntos:
vi_translation: Then suddenly he wrote - simply because he was scared, he didn't even know what he was writing anymore. He wrote lines that went up and down like a child's, at first forgetting to capitalize and then forgetting to punctuate altogether.
tr_translation: Suddenly, he began writing in a panic, not quite aware of what he was scribbling. His small, childlike handwriting wandered across the page, first abandoning capital letters, then punctuation marks.
es_translation: Suddenly, he began to write with great speed, as if driven by panic, barely aware of what he was writing. With his childish handwriting, he was drawing crooked lines, and if at first he started to "omit" the capital letters, he later even omitted the periods:

en: April 4th, 1984. Last night to the flicks. All warfilms. One very good one of a ship full of refugees being bombed somewhere in the Mediterranean. Audience much amused by shots of a great huge fat man trying to swim away with a helicopter after him. first you saw him wallowing along in the water like a porpoise, then you saw him through the helicopters gunsights, then he was full of holes and the sea round him turned pink and he sank as suddenly as though the holes had let in the water. audience shouting with laughter when he sank. then you saw a lifeboat full of children with a helicopter hovering over it. there was a middleaged woman might have been a jewess sitting up in the bow with a little boy about three years old in her arms. little boy screaming with fright and hiding his head between her breasts as if he was trying to burrow right into her and the woman putting her arms round him and comforting him although she was blue with fright herself. all the time covering him up as much as possible as if she thought her arms could keep the bullets off him. then the helicopter planted a 20 kilo bomb in among them terrific flash and the boat went all to matchwood. then there was a wonderful shot of a childs arm going up up up right up into the air a helicopter with a camera in its nose must have followed it up and there was a lot of applause from the party seats but a woman down in the prole part of the house suddenly started kicking up a fuss and shouting they didnt oughter of showed it not in front of kids they didnt it aint right not in front of kids it aint until the police turned her turned her out i dont suppose anything happened to her nobody cares what the proles say typical prole reaction they never—
vi: Ngày 4 tháng tư năm 1984. Hôm qua đi xem phim. Toàn phim chiến đấu. Một phim hay, một chiếc tàu thuỷ đầy người tị nạn ở Địa Trung Hải bị ném bom. Cả khán phòng thích chí khi xem cảnh một gã đàn ông to lớn đang bơi, trong khi một chiếc trực thăng đuổi theo sau, đầu tiên thấy gã lặn hụp như cá heo, sau đó thấy gã qua ống ngắm từ trên máy bay, sau đó gã bị bắn thủng lỗ chỗ như mặt sàng, mặt biển bỗng biến thành màu hồng, gã chìm nhanh y như nước bị hút qua các lỗ thủng trên người vậy. khi gã chìm đến đáy thì cả khán phòng phá lên cười. Sau đó là một cái xuồng đầy trẻ con, bên trên lại một chiếc trực thăng nữa. trên mũi xuồng là một người phụ nữ trung niên, có lẽ là Do Thái, tay bế một đứa nhỏ chừng ba tuổi. Đứa nhỏ gào lên vì sợ, đầu cứ dúi vào ngực mẹ còn bà ta thì vừa vỗ về vừa lấy tay che cho con mặc dù chính bà ta cũng sợ, mặt xanh như tầu lá. bà ta lấy tay che cho con, làm như có thể ngăn được đạn không bằng. sau đó cái trực thăng ném xuống một quả bom loại hai mươi cân tiếng nổ kinh hoàng và cái thuyền tan ra thành từng mảnh vụn. sau đó là một cảnh tuyệt vời một cánh tay trẻ con bay lên, vọt thẳng lên trời chắc là người ta quay từ mũi chiếc trực thăng và những tiếng vỗ tay ồn ào vang lên từ những hàng ghế dành riêng cho đảng viên nhưng từ chỗ dành cho bọn cu li thì có một phụ bỗng gào lên, bà ta bảo không được chiếu những cảnh đó cho trẻ con xem và cứ thế cho đến khi cảnh sát phải lôi phải lôi bà ta ra chắc là họ chẳng làm gì đâu bọn cu li thì chấp làm gì phản ứng của chúng vẫn thế ai thèm quan tâm…
tr: 14 Nisan 1948. Dün gece sinemada. Hepsi savaş filmleri, iyi olan birinde, bir gemi dolusu mülteci, Akdeniz'de bir yerlerde bombalandı. Şişman, iriyarı bir adamın, ardında helikopter, yüzmeye çabalayan görüntüsü izleyicileri pek eğlendirdi, önce adamın yunus balığı gibi debelendiğini, sonra helikopterlerin silâh atış alanı içine girdiğini gördük, sonra delik deşik oldu ve çevresindeki deniz suyu pembeye bayandı ve bedenindeki delikler suyun içeri girmesine izin vermiş gibi ansızın battı. O batarken izleyiciler gülmekten katılıyorlar, sonra bir helikopterin üzerinde uçmakta olduğu, içi çocuk dolu bir kurtarma botu gördük. Önde kucağında üç yaşlarında küçük bir çocukla orta yaşlı bir kadın oturuyordu, Yahudi'ydi belki de, küçük çocuk korkuyla bağırmakta ve kendisini gömmek ister gibi başını annesinin göğüsleri arasına sokmakta, kadın kendisi korkudan mosmor olduğu halde çocuğu avutmaya çalışıyor ve kollan gelen mermilerden koruyabilecekmiş gibi oğlunu sarabildiğince sarıyor, helikopter üzerlerine yirmi kiloluk bir bomba fırlattı, müthiş bir patlama oldu ve bot küçük kıymıklara ayrıldı, sonra bir çocuk kolunun gökyüzüne doğru uçtuğu müthiş bir sahne vardı, burnunda bir kamera bulunan helikopter izlemiş olmalıydı onu, Parti üyelerinin bulunduğu sıralarda alkış koptu, ama sinemanın proleter kısmındaki bir kadın ansızın ayaklarını yere vurmaya ve bunları çocukların önünde göstermeye haklan yok diye bağırmaya başladı, polis onu durdurana dek, bunları çocukların önünde göstermeye haklan yok, hayır gösteremezler çocuklara, ona bir şey yaptıklarını sanmıyorum, kimse proleterlerin söylediklerine kulak asmaz, tipik proleter tepkisi, hiçbir zaman.
es: 4 de abril de 1984. Anoche estuve en los flicks. Todas las películas eran de guerra. Había una muy buena de un barco lleno de refugiados que lo bombardeaban en no sé dónde del Mediterráneo. Al público le divirtieron mucho dar planos de un hombre muy grande y muy gordo que intentaba escaparse nadando de un helicóptero que lo perseguía, Primero se le veía en el agua chapoteando como una tortuga, luego lo veías por los visores de las ametralladoras del helicóptero, luego se veía cómo lo iban agujereando a tiros y el agua a su alrededor que se ponía toda roja y el gordo se hundía como si el agua le entrase por los agujeros que le habían hecho las balas. La gente se moría de risa cuando el gordo se iba hundiendo en el agua, y también una lancha salvavidas llena de niños con un helicóptero que venga a darle vueltas y más vueltas había una mujer de edad madura que bien podía ser una judía y estaba sentada en la proa con un niño en los brazos que quizás tuviera unos tres años. El niño chillaba con mucho pánico, metía la cabeza entre los pechos de la mujer y parecía que se quería esconder así y la mujer lo rodeaba con los brazos y lo consolaba como si ella no estuviese también aterrada y como si por tenerlo así en los brazos fuera a evitar que le alcanzaran al niño las balas. Entonces va el helicóptero y tira una bomba de veinte kilos sobre el bote y no queda ni una astilla de él, que fue una explosión pero que magnífica, y luego salía un primer plano maravilloso del brazo del niño subiendo por el aire yo creo que un helicóptero con su cámara debe haberlo seguido así por el aire y la gente aplaudió muchísimo pero una mujer que estaba entre los proletarios empezó a armar un escándalo terrible chillando que no debían echar eso no debían echarlo delante de los críos que no debían hasta que la policía la sacó de allí a rastras no creo que le pasara nada a nadie le importa lo que dicen los proletarios porque dicen es la reacción típica de las proletarias y nadie hace caso y nunca...
vi_translation: April 4th, 1984. Went to see a movie yesterday. All war movies. A good movie, a ship full of refugees in the Mediterranean was bombed. The whole auditorium was delighted watching a big man swimming, while a helicopter chased after him, first seeing him dive like a dolphin, then seeing him through the scope from the plane, then he was shot full of holes like a sieve, the sea suddenly turned pink, he sank quickly as if the water was being sucked through the holes in his body. When he sank to the bottom, the whole auditorium burst into laughter. Then there was a boat full of children, with another helicopter above. At the bow of the boat was a middle-aged woman, probably Jewish, holding a small child about three years old. The child screamed in fear, burying its head in its mother's chest while she comforted it and tried to shield it with her hand even though she was also scared, her face pale as a leaf. She shielded the child with her hand, as if that could stop the bullets. Then the helicopter dropped a twenty-pound bomb, the explosion was terrifying and the boat shattered into pieces. Then there was a wonderful scene of a child's arm flying up, shooting straight into the sky, probably filmed from the nose of the helicopter, and loud applause erupted from the seats reserved for party members, but from the seats for the proles, a woman suddenly screamed, saying that such scenes shouldn't be shown to children, and kept on until the police had to drag her out. They probably wouldn't do anything; the proles' reactions are always like that, who cares...
tr_translation: April 14, 1948. Last night at the cinema. They were all war movies; in a good one, a ship full of refugees was bombed somewhere in the Mediterranean. The image of a fat, burly man struggling to swim, with a helicopter behind him. It greatly amused the audience; first, we saw the man flailing like a dolphin, then the helicopters entered the firing range, then he was riddled with bullets, and the surrounding seawater turned pink, and as if the holes in his body allowed the water to enter, he suddenly sank. As he sank, the audience was doubled over with laughter, then we saw a rescue boat full of children over which a helicopter was flying. In the front sat a middle-aged woman with a small child of about three years old in her lap, she might have been Jewish, the small child was screaming in fear and trying to bury his head between his mother's breasts as if to hide, the woman, though herself pale with fear, was trying to comfort the child and hugging him as tightly as she could as if she could protect him from the incoming bullets, the helicopter dropped a twenty-kilogram bomb on them, there was a tremendous explosion and the boat was shattered into small pieces, then there was an incredible scene of a child's arm flying towards the sky, a helicopter with a camera on its nose must have captured it, applause broke out in the rows where the Party members were seated, but a woman in the proletarian section of the cinema suddenly started stamping her feet and shouting that they had no right to show this in front of children, no, they can't show this to children, I don't think they did anything to her, no one pays attention to what the proletarians say, typical proletarian reaction, never.
es_translation: April 4, 1984. Last night I was at the flicks. All the movies were about war. There was a very good one about a ship full of refugees being bombed somewhere in the Mediterranean. The audience was greatly amused by shots of a very big and very fat man trying to escape by swimming from a helicopter that was chasing him. First, you saw him in the water splashing around like a turtle, then you saw him through the helicopter's machine gun sights, then you saw him being riddled with bullets and the water around him turning all red, and the fat man sinking as if the water was entering through the holes the bullets had made. People were dying of laughter as the fat man sank into the water, and also at a lifeboat full of children with a helicopter circling around and around. There was a middle-aged woman who could well have been Jewish, sitting in the bow with a child in her arms who might have been about three years old. The child was screaming in great panic, burying his head between the woman's breasts as if trying to hide, and the woman was holding him and comforting him as if she herself were not also terrified, and as if by holding him like that in her arms she could prevent the bullets from reaching him. Then the helicopter dropped a twenty-kilo bomb on the boat, and there wasn't a splinter left of it. What an explosion, but magnificent, and then there was a wonderful close-up of the child's arm flying through the air. I think a helicopter with its camera must have followed it through the air, and the audience applauded a lot, but a woman among the proles started making a terrible fuss, screaming that they shouldn't show that, shouldn't show it in front of the kids, until the police dragged her out of there. I don't think anything happened to her; nobody cares what the proles say because they say it's the typical reaction of the proles, and nobody pays attention and never...

en: His eyes refocused on the page. He discovered that while he sat helplessly musing he had also been writing, as though by automatic action. And it was no longer the same cramped, awkward handwriting as before. His pen had slid voluptuously over the smooth paper, printing in large neat capitals—
vi: Anh lại nhìn chằm chằm vào tờ giấy. Anh phát hiện ra rằng trong khi suy nghĩ một cách bất lực như thế thì tay vẫn viết, hoàn toàn tự động. Nhưng đây không phải là những chữ xấu xí, run rẩy như lúc đầu. Ngòi bút khoan khoái trượt trên mặt giấy nhẵn bóng, tạo nên những chữ in to, rõ ràng:
tr: Gözleri yeniden önündeki sayfaya çevrildi. Çaresiz düşünceler içinde kıvranırken, farkında olmadan bir şeyler yazmış olduğunu gördü. Bu, öncekiler gibi kargacık burgacık bir karalama değildi. Kalemi, yumuşacık kâğıdın üzerinde ihtirasla gezinmiş ve hep büyük harflerle, tekrar tekrar şunları yazmıştı:
es: Volvieron a fijarse sus ojos en la página. Descubrió entonces que durante todo el tiempo en que había estado recordando, no había dejado de escribir como por una acción automática. Y ya no era la inhábil escritura retorcida de antes. Su pluma se había deslizado voluptuosamente sobre el suave papel, imprimiendo en claras y grandes mayúsculas lo siguiente:
vi_translation: He stared intently at the piece of paper again. He discovered that while he was thinking helplessly like that, his hand kept writing, completely automatically. But these were not the ugly, shaky letters from the beginning. The pen glided smoothly over the glossy paper, creating large, clear printed letters:
tr_translation: His eyes turned back to the page in front of him. While writhing in helpless thoughts, he saw that he had written something without realizing it. This was not a messy scribble like the previous ones. His pen had passionately roamed over the soft paper and had repeatedly written the following in all capital letters:
es_translation: Their eyes returned to the page. He then discovered that during all the time he had been remembering, he had not stopped writing as if by an automatic action. And it was no longer the awkward twisted writing from before. His pen had slid voluptuously over the smooth paper, imprinting the following in clear and large capital letters:

en: He could not help feeling a twinge of panic. It was absurd, since the writing of those particular words was not more dangerous than the initial act of opening the diary; but for a moment he was tempted to tear out the spoiled pages and abandon the enterprise altogether.
vi: Anh cảm thấy hoảng sợ vô cùng. Thật vô nghĩa, bởi vì viết những chữ cụ thể đó cũng không nguy hiểm hơn việc ghi nhật kí, thế mà anh bỗng nảy ra ý định xé trang giấy và chấm dứt luôn toàn bộ công việc.
tr: Sancıya benzer bir panik duydu içinde. Ama saçmaydı bu. Birtakım sözleri yazmak en az bir günlük tutma eylemi kadar tehlikeliydi. Bir an için sayfaları yırtıp atmak ve günlük tutma girişimine son vermek istedi.
es: No pudo evitar un escalofrío de pánico. Era absurdo, ya que escribir aquellas palabras no era más peligroso que el acto inicial de abrir un diario; pero, por un instante, estuvo tentado de romper las páginas ya escritas y abandonar su propósito.
vi_translation: He felt extremely terrified. It was utterly meaningless, because writing those specific words was no more dangerous than keeping a diary, yet he suddenly had the urge to tear the page and put an end to the entire task.
tr_translation: He felt a panic similar to pain inside. But this was absurd. Writing down certain words was as dangerous as the act of keeping a diary. For a moment, he wanted to tear up the pages and put an end to the diary-keeping attempt.
es_translation: He couldn't avoid a shiver of panic. It was absurd, since writing those words was no more dangerous than the initial act of opening a diary; but, for a moment, he was tempted to tear up the already written pages and abandon his purpose.

en: He sat back in his chair, slightly ashamed of himself, and laid down the pen. The next moment he started violently. There was a knocking at the door.
vi: Anh ngả lưng ra thành ghế, thâm tâm cảm thấy xấu hổ, tay buông bút. Anh bỗng giật nảy mình. Có người gõ cửa.
tr: Arkasına yaslandı, biraz kendinden utanmıştı, kalemini bıraktı. Bir an sonra şiddetle irkildi. Kapı çalınıyordu.
es: Se echó hacia atrás en la silla, un poco avergonzado de sí mismo, y dejó la pluma sobre la mesa. De repente, se sobresaltó espantosamente. Habían llamado a la puerta.
vi_translation: He leaned back against the chair, feeling ashamed deep down, and let go of the pen. He suddenly started. Someone knocked on the door.
tr_translation: He leaned back, feeling a bit ashamed of himself, and put down his pen. A moment later, he started violently. The door was knocking.
es_translation: He leaned back in the chair, a little embarrassed with himself, and placed the pen on the table. Suddenly, he was terribly startled. Someone had knocked on the door.

en: “Oh, comrade,” she began in a dreary, whining sort of voice, “I thought I heard you come in. Do you think you could come across and have a look at our kitchen sink? It’s got blocked up and—”
vi: “A, đồng chí”, bà ta nói, giọng the thé, khó chịu. “Đúng là tôi đã nghe thấy anh về. Anh có thể xem hộ tôi cái bồn rửa bát trong bếp được không? Nó bị tắc”
tr: "Ah, yoldaş!" diye başladı kasvetli, zırıldar gibi bir sesle. "Geldiğinizi duydum. Acaba biraz gelir, mutfak lavabomuza bir göz atabilir misiniz? Tıkanmış da.
es: —¡Oh, camarada! —empezó a decir la mujer en una voz lúgubre y quejumbrosa—; te sentí llegar y he venido por si puedes echarle un ojo al desagüe del fregadero. Se nos ha atascado...
vi_translation: “Ah, comrade,” she said, her voice shrill and unpleasant. “I did hear that you were back. Can you take a look at the kitchen sink for me? It's clogged.”
tr_translation: "Ah, comrade!" he began in a gloomy, whining voice. "I heard you came. I wonder if you could come and take a look at our kitchen sink? It's clogged."
es_translation: —Oh, comrade! —the woman began to say in a gloomy and plaintive voice—; I felt you arrive and I came to see if you could take a look at the sink drain. It has gotten clogged...

en: “Attention! Your attention, please! A newsflash has this moment arrived from the Malabar front. Our forces in South India have won a glorious victory. I am authorized to say that the action we are now reporting may well bring the war within measurable distance of its end. Here is the newsflash—”
vi: "Chú ý! Chú ý! Chúng tôi vừa nhận được bản tin nhanh từ mặt trận Malabar. Quân đội ta trên mặt trận Nam Ấn vừa giành được một chiến thắng hết sức quan trọng. Tôi được phép tuyên bố rằng kết quả chiến dịch này là điềm báo ngày kết thúc chiến tranh không còn bao xa nữa. Xin mời nghe bản tin nhanh".
tr: "Dikkat! Dikkat! Malabar cephesine ilişkin, en son aldığımız haberleri veriyoruz. Kuvvetlerimiz, Güney Hindistan'da görkemli bir zafer kazandılar. Bu başarının savaşın bitimini engelleyeceğini söylemek yanlış olmaz. Şimdi haberler:"
es: «Atención. ¡Vuestra atención, por favor! En este momento nos llega un notirrelámpago del frente malabar. Nuestras fuerzas han logrado una gloriosa victoria en el sur de la India. Estoy autorizado para decir que la batalla a que me refiero puede aproximarnos bastante al final de la guerra. He aquí el texto del notirrelámpago...»
vi_translation: "Attention! Attention! We have just received a breaking news report from the Malabar front. Our army on the South Indian front has just achieved a very significant victory. I am authorized to declare that the outcome of this campaign is a harbinger that the end of the war is not far off. Please listen to the breaking news report."
tr_translation: "Attention! Attention! We are giving the latest news regarding the Malabar front. Our forces have achieved a magnificent victory in South India. It would not be wrong to say that this success will prevent the end of the war. Now, the news:"
es_translation: "Attention." "Your attention, please!" "At this moment, we receive a newsflash from the Malabar front." "Our forces have achieved a glorious victory in the south of India." "I am authorized to say that the battle I am referring to may bring us quite close to the end of the war." "Here is the text of the newsflash..."

en: Curiously, the chiming of the hour seemed to have put new heart into him. He was a lonely ghost uttering a truth that nobody would ever hear. But so long as he uttered it, in some obscure way the continuity was not broken. It was not by making yourself heard but by staying sane that you carried on the human heritage. He went back to the table, dipped his pen, and wrote:
vi: Có điều lạ là dường như tiếng chuông đồng hồ đã tiếp thêm cho anh sức mạnh. Anh là một con ma cô đơn đang nói sự thật, sự thật không bao giờ có người nghe. Nhưng anh nói nghĩa là sự liên tục vẫn còn, dù rất mù mờ. Không phải bằng cách làm cho người ta nghe được mình mà là bằng cách không hoá điên, tiếp tục giữ vững di sản của loài người. Anh trở lại bên bàn viết, chấm mực và ghi:
tr: Garip, ama saatin vuruşuyla, yiten cesareti geri gelmişti. O, kimsenin duyup öğrenemeyeceği bir gerçeği mırıldanıyordu ve bu sürdükçe, düşünceler sürekliliğini yitirmeyecekti. Önemli olan, sesini duyurmak değildi; aklını koruyarak, insanlığın mirasını sürdürmekti. Yeniden masasına döndü, kalemini mürekkebe batırdı ve yazmaya başladı:
es: Qué curioso: las campanadas de la hora lo reanimaron. Era como un fantasma solitario diciendo una verdad que nadie oiría nunca. De todos modos, mientras Winston pronunciara esa verdad, la continuidad no se rompía. La herencia humana no se continuaba porque uno se hiciera oír sino por el hecho de permanecer cuerdo. Volvió a la mesa, mojó en tinta su pluma y escribió:
vi_translation: Strangely, it seemed that the sound of the clock's chime had given him strength. He was a lonely ghost speaking the truth, a truth that no one ever heard. But his speaking meant that continuity still existed, though very faintly. Not by making people hear him, but by not going mad, continuing to uphold the heritage of humanity. He returned to the writing desk, dipped his pen in ink, and wrote: Recipient:
tr_translation: Strange, but with the stroke of the clock, his lost courage had returned. He was murmuring a truth that no one could hear or learn, and as long as this continued, his thoughts would not lose continuity. The important thing was not to make his voice heard; it was to preserve his mind and continue the legacy of humanity. He returned to his desk, dipped his pen in ink, and began to write:
es_translation: How curious: the chimes of the hour revived him. It was like a lonely ghost saying a truth that no one would ever hear. Anyway, as long as Winston pronounced that truth, the continuity was not broken. The human heritage was not continued by making oneself heard but by remaining sane. He returned to the table, dipped his pen in ink, and wrote:

en: To the future or to the past, to a time when thought is free, when men are different from one another and do not live alone—to a time when truth exists and what is done cannot be undone:
vi: Người nhận: Tương lai hay là quá khứ, thời đại của tự do tư tưởng, khi không ai giống ai, khi ai sống ở nhà nấy - thời đại khi sự thật vẫn còn và cái đã tồn tại không bị biến thành tro bụi:
tr: Geleceğe ya da geçmişe, düşüncelerin özgür olduğu, insanların birbirlerinden farklı olduğu, ama yalnız yaşamadığı bir zamana, gerçeğin var olduğu ve yapılmış bir şeyin yok edilemeyeceği bir za- mana:
es: Para el futuro o para el pasado, para la época en que se pueda pensar libremente, en que los hombres sean distintos unos de otros y no vivan solitarios... Para cuando la verdad exista y lo que se haya hecho no pueda ser deshecho:
vi_translation: The future or the past, the era of free thought, when no one is the same, when everyone lives in their own home - the era when truth still exists and what has existed has not turned to ashes: Sender:
tr_translation: To a time in the future or the past, where thoughts are free, people are different from each other, but not living alone, where truth exists and something that has been done cannot be destroyed, a ti- mana:
es_translation: For the future or for the past, for the time when one can think freely, when men are different from one another and do not live in solitude... For when the truth exists and what has been done cannot be undone:

en: At this moment his mother was sitting in some place deep down beneath him, with his young sister in her arms. He did not remember his sister at all, except as a tiny, feeble baby, always silent, with large, watchful eyes. Both of them were looking up at him. They were down in some subterranean place—the bottom of a well, for instance, or a very deep grave—but it was a place which, already far below him, was itself moving downwards. They were in the saloon of a sinking ship, looking up at him through the darkening water. There was still air in the saloon, they could still see him and he them, but all the while they were sinking down, down into the green waters which in another moment must hide them from sight forever. He was out in the light and air while they were being sucked down to death, and they were down there because he was up here. He knew it and they knew it, and he could see the knowledge in their faces. There was no reproach either in their faces or in their hearts, only the knowledge that they must die in order that he might remain alive, and that this was part of the unavoidable order of things.
vi: Trong mơ mẹ ngồi bên dưới, sâu lắm, tay đang bế cô em gái. Anh hoàn toàn không nhớ gì về cô em cả, ngoại trừ hình ảnh đấy là một đứa nhỏ ốm yếu, đôi mắt to, lặng lẽ quan sát, không bao giờ khóc. Cả hai đang nhìn vào anh. Họ ngồi ở dưới lòng đất - trong lòng một cái giếng, mà cũng có thể dưới mồ sâu - và đang hạ xuống ngày một sâu hơn. Họ ngồi trong buồng một con tàu đang chìm và nhìn lên Winston qua làn nước màu đen. Trong buồng vẫn còn không khí, họ còn nhìn thấy anh và anh thấy họ, nhưng họ đang chìm dần vào làn nước xanh và chỉ chút nữa nữa là sẽ biến mất hoàn toàn. Anh ở ngoài không khí, ngoài ánh sáng còn họ thì đang bị hút vào chỗ chết, họ bị hút xuống vì anh đang ở trên này. Anh biết thế, họ cũng biết thế, nhìn mặt họ là thấy. Trên nét mặt hay trong tim họ không hề có lời oán trách nào, chỉ có nhận thức rằng họ phải chết để anh được sống vì qui luật là như thế.
tr: Düşünde annesi, kollarında kızkardeşi aşağılarda bir yerlerde oturuyordu. Kızkardeşini hiç anımsamıyordu, belleğinde kalan, yalnızca onun zayıf, ufacık, hep sessiz duran, kocaman gözleriyle etrafı izleyen bir bebek olduğuydu. Her ikisi de yukarı, ona doğru bakıyorlardı. Karanlık bir yerdeydiler, bir kuyunun dibi olabilirdi ya da derin bir mezar, ama dipte olmasına karşın, sürekli daha derinlere batan bir yerdeydiler. Karanlık sulara gömülen, batan bir geminin salonundaydılar. İçeride hâlâ hava vardı, onlar kendisini, o da onları görebiliyordu, ama bir süre sonra yeşil sulara gömülecekler ve tümden kaybolacaklardı. O ise açık havadaydı, ışıklı bir yerdeydi, kardeşi ve annesi ölüme yaklaşırken kendisi yukarıda olduğu için onlar dipteydiler. Bunu biliyordu; onlar da biliyorlardı ve bunu onların yüzünden okuyabiliyordu. Ne gönüllerinde, ne de yüzlerinde, herhangi bir suçlama yoktu; yalnızca, onun yaşaması için ölmeleri gerektiğini biliyorlardı ve bu, kaçınılmaz düzenin parçasıydı.
es: En aquel momento —en el sueño— su madre estaba sentada en un sitio profundo junto a él y con su niña en brazos. De esta hermana sólo recordaba Winston que era una chiquilla débil e insignificante, siempre callada y con ojos grandes que se fijaban en todo. Se hallaban las dos en algún sitio subterráneo —por ejemplo, el fondo de un pozo o en una cueva muy honda—, pero era un lugar que, estando ya muy por debajo de él, se iba hundiendo sin cesar. Sí, era la cámara de un barco que se hundía y la madre y la hermana lo miraban a él desde la tenebrosidad de las aguas que invadían el buque. Aún había aire en la cámara. Su madre y su hermanita podían verlo todavía y él a ellas, pero no dejaban de irse hundiendo ni un solo instante, de ir cayendo en las aguas, de un verde muy oscuro, que de un momento a otro las ocultarían para siempre. Winston, en cambio, se encontraba al aire libre y a plena luz mientras a ellas se las iba tragando la muerte, y ellas se hundían porque él estaba allí arriba. Winston lo sabía y también ellas lo sabían y él descubría en las caras de ellas este conocimiento. Pero la expresión de las dos no le reprochaba nada ni sus corazones tampoco —él lo sabía— y sólo se transparentaba la convicción de que ellas morían para que él pudiera seguir viviendo allá arriba y que esto formaba parte del orden inevitable de las cosas.
vi_translation: In the dream, mother was sitting below, very deep, holding his little sister. He completely did not remember anything about the little sister, except that she was a frail child with big eyes, quietly observing, never crying. Both of them were looking at him. They were sitting underground - in the heart of a well, or perhaps in a deep grave - and were descending deeper and deeper. They were sitting in the cabin of a sinking ship and looking up at Winston through the black water. There was still air in the cabin, they could still see him and he could see them, but they were gradually sinking into the blue water and would soon disappear completely. He was outside in the air, in the light, while they were being drawn into death, they were being pulled down because he was up here. He knew it, they knew it too, it was evident on their faces. On their faces or in their hearts, there was no blame, only the understanding that they had to die for him to live because that was the rule.
tr_translation: In his dream, his mother, with his sister in her arms, was sitting somewhere below. He did not remember his sister at all; what remained in his memory was only that she was a weak, tiny baby, always silent, watching everything with her big eyes. Both of them were looking up at him. They were in a dark place, it could have been the bottom of a well or a deep grave, but despite being at the bottom, they were in a place that kept sinking deeper. They were in the hall of a sinking ship submerged in dark waters. There was still air inside, they could see him, and he could see them, but for a while then they would be submerged in the green waters and disappear completely. But he was in the open air, in a bright place, while his brother and mother were approaching death, he was above, so they were at the bottom. He knew this; they knew it too, and he could read it from their faces. There was no blame in their hearts or on their faces; they simply knew that they had to die for him to live, and this was part of the inevitable order.
es_translation: At that moment —in the dream— his mother was sitting in a deep place next to him with his little girl in her arms. Of this sister, Winston only remembered that she was a weak and insignificant little girl, always quiet and with big eyes that fixed on everything. The two of them were in some underground place —for example, the bottom of a well or a very deep cave— but it was a place that, already far below him, kept sinking without ceasing. Yes, it was the cabin of a sinking ship and the mother and sister looked at him from the darkness of the waters invading the ship. There was still air in the cabin. His mother and little sister could still see him and he could see them, but they kept sinking without a single moment's pause, falling into the waters, very dark green, which would hide them forever at any moment. Winston, on the other hand, was in the open air and in full light while they were being swallowed by death, and they were sinking because he was up there. Winston knew it and they knew it too, and he discovered this knowledge in their faces. But the expression of the two did not reproach him at all, nor did their hearts —he knew it— and only the conviction that they were dying so that he could continue living up there was transparent, and that this was part of the inevitable order of things.

en: Suddenly he was standing on short springy turf, on a summer evening when the slanting rays of the sun gilded the ground. The landscape that he was looking at recurred so often in his dreams that he was never fully certain whether or not he had seen it in the real world. In his waking thoughts he called it the Golden Country. It was an old, rabbit-bitten pasture, with a foot track wandering across it and a molehill here and there. In the ragged hedge on the opposite side of the field the boughs of the elm trees were swaying very faintly in the breeze, their leaves just stirring in dense masses like women’s hair. Somewhere near at hand, though out of sight, there was a clear, slow-moving stream where dace were swimming in the pools under the willow trees.
vi: Bất ngờ anh thấy mình đang đứng trên một thảm cỏ cắt ngắn, trong một buổi chiều mùa hè, ánh mặt trời chiếu xiên khoai. Anh thường mơ thấy chỗ này nên không thể biết chắc đã thật sự nhìn thấy nó bao giờ hay chưa. Khi thức anh gọi chỗ đó là Địa Hoàng. Đấy là một bãi cỏ cằn cỗi, bị thỏ gặm nham nhở, có một con đường mòn nhỏ chạy vắt ngang, hang chuột đùn lên khắp nơi. Phía cuối bãi cỏ là hàng du đung đưa, tán lá dầy phấp phới như tóc đàn bà bay trước gió. Ở đâu đó rất gần, tuy không trông thấy, là tiếng nước róc rách, nơi những con cá nhỏ đang bơi dưới bóng liễu thướt tha.
tr: Birden batan güneşin, toprağa altın rengini verdiği bir yaz akşamında, yumuşak bir çimenliğin üzerinde buldu kendini. Karşısındaki görüntü, düşlerinde o kadar sık yer almıştı ki, bunun gerçek olup olmadığını kestiremiyordu. Uyanıkken bile onu dolduran bu yere Altın Ülke adını vermişti. Yer yer tavşanlar tarafından kemirilmiş, tek tük köstebek yuvalarının yer aldığı, ortasından bir keçiyolu geçen eskilere ait bir çimenlikti bu. Karşı taraftaki çitin kenarındaki kara ağaçlar, esen hafif meltemlerle, gür kadın saçı gibi, ağır ağır, bir o yana, bir bu yana sallanıyorlardı. Görünmemesine karşın yakınlarda bir yerlerde olduğunu bildiği, nazlı nazlı akan bir çayın sularında, söğüt ağaçlarının gölgesinde, balıklar yüzüyordu.
es: De pronto, se vio de pie sobre el césped en una tarde de verano en que los rayos oblicuos del sol doraban la corta hierba. El paisaje que se le aparecía ahora se le presentaba con tanta frecuencia en sueños que nunca estaba completamente seguro de si lo había visto alguna vez en la vida real. Cuando estaba despierto, lo llamaba el País Dorado. Lo cubrían pastos mordidos por los conejos con un sendero que serpenteaba por él y, aquí y allá, unas pequeñísimas elevaciones del terreno. Al fondo, se veían unos olmos que se balanceaban suavemente con la brisa y sus follajes parecían cabelleras de mujer. Cerca, aunque fuera de la vista, corría un claro arroyuelo de lento fluir.
vi_translation: Suddenly he found himself standing on a short-cut lawn, on a summer afternoon, with the sun casting long shadows. He often dreamed of this place, so he couldn't be sure if he had ever actually seen it before. When awake, he called that place the Earthly Realm. It was a barren lawn, nibbled unevenly by rabbits, with a small path running across it, and mouse holes popping up everywhere. At the end of the lawn was a row of elms swaying, their thick foliage fluttering like women's hair in the wind. Somewhere very close, though unseen, was the sound of water trickling, where small fish were swimming under the graceful willows' shade.
tr_translation: On a summer evening when the suddenly setting sun gave the earth a golden hue, he found himself on a soft grassy field. The scene before him had appeared so often in his dreams that he couldn't tell if it was real or not. He had named this place, which filled him even when awake, the Golden Land. This was an old grassy field, nibbled here and there by rabbits, with a few molehills, and a goat path running through its middle. The black trees by the fence on the opposite side swayed slowly, like thick women's hair, back and forth in the gentle breeze. Although it wasn't visible, he knew that somewhere nearby, in the waters of a lazily flowing stream, under the shade of willow trees, fish were swimming.
es_translation: Suddenly, he found himself standing on the grass on a summer afternoon when the oblique rays of the sun gilded the short grass. The landscape that now appeared before him presented itself so frequently in dreams that he was never completely sure if he had ever seen it in real life. When he was awake, he called it the Golden Country. It was covered with grass nibbled by rabbits with a path winding through it and, here and there, some tiny elevations of the terrain. In the background, some elms swayed gently with the breeze, and their foliage looked like women's hair. Nearby, though out of sight, ran a clear, slow-flowing stream.

en: His earlier thought returned to him: probably she was not actually a member of the Thought Police, but then it was precisely the amateur spy who was the greatest danger of all. He did not know how long she had been looking at him, but perhaps for as much as five minutes, and it was possible that his features had not been perfectly under control. It was terribly dangerous to let your thoughts wander when you were in any public place or within range of a telescreen. The smallest thing could give you away. A nervous tic, an unconscious look of anxiety, a habit of muttering to yourself—anything that carried with it the suggestion of abnormality, of having something to hide. In any case, to wear an improper expression on your face (to look incredulous when a victory was announced, for example) was itself a punishable offense. There was even a word for it in Newspeak: facecrime, it was called.
vi: Anh lại nghĩ như trước: có thể cô ta không phải là nhân viên của Cảnh Sát Tư Tưởng, nhưng chính bọn nghiệp dư còn đáng sợ hơn. Anh không biết cô ta đã theo dõi bao lâu, có thể khoảng năm phút, anh cũng không biết vừa rồi mình có giữ đúng tư thế hay không. Ở nơi công cộng hay trong vùng quan sát của màn vô tuyến mà tỏ ra đăm chiêu là nguy to. Chỉ một chút vô tình là coi như xong. Chỉ cần một cái máy mắt, một biểu hiện lo lắng, thói quen lẩm bẩm một mình, hay bất kì biểu hiện bất bình thường hay ý định che giấu một cái gì đó là xong. Chỉ cần nét mặt không phù hợp (thí dụ tỏ không tin khi nghe thông báo thành tích) cũng bị trừng trị rồi. Ngômo gọi đấy là: mặtội, tội lỗi thể hiện trên nét mặt.
tr: İlk düşüncesi geri geldi, herhalde bir Düşünce Polisi değildi, ama amatör bir casus olabilirdi. Ve en büyük tehlike de onlardan gelirdi. Onun kendisine ne kadar zamandır baktığını bilmiyordu, beş dakikadır izliyor olabilirdi ve bu zaman içerisinde kendi yüzündeki anlatımı denetleyip denetlemediğinin pek farkında değildi. Bir tele ekran görüş alanı içinde ya da genel bir yerde, düşüncelerini serbest akışına bırakmak hiç doğru değildi. En ufak bir şey; sinirsel bir tik, kederli bir görünüş, kendi kendine bir şeyler mırıldanma huyu, olağandışılık ya da bazı şeylerin gizlendiği kanısını uyandırabilecek her şey sizi ele vermeye yetebilirdi. Yüzünüze uygunsuz bir anlatım vermek, (örneğin bir zafer açıklanırken, şaşkın bir tavır takınmak) ceza gerektirecek bir suç sayılırdı. Yenikonuşta bunun da karşılığı olan bir sözcük vardı; yüzsuçu deniliyordu buna.
es: Pensó que probablemente la muchacha no era miembro de la Policía del Pensamiento, pero precisamente las espías aficionadas constituían el mayor peligro. No sabía Winston cuánto tiempo llevaba mirándolo la joven, pero quizás fueran cinco minutos. Era muy posible que en este tiempo no hubiera podido controlar sus gestos a la perfección. Constituía un terrible peligro pensar mientras se estaba en un sitio público o al alcance de la telepantalla. El detalle más pequeño podía traicionarle a uno. Un tic nervioso, una inconsciente mirada de inquietud, la costumbre de hablar con uno mismo entre dientes, todo lo que revelase la necesidad de ocultar algo. En todo caso, llevar en el rostro una expresión impropia (por ejemplo, parecer incrédulo cuando se anunciaba una victoria) constituía un acto punible. Incluso había una palabra para esto en neolengua: caracrimen.
vi_translation: He thought again as before: maybe she wasn't an employee of the Thought Police, but the amateurs were even more frightening. He didn't know how long she had been watching, maybe about five minutes, and he also didn't know if he had maintained the correct posture just now. In public places or within the observation range of the telescreen, appearing pensive was dangerous. Just a little carelessness and it would be over. Just a blink, a worried expression, a habit of muttering to oneself, or any unusual behavior or intent to hide something, and it would be over. Even a facial expression that didn't match (for example, showing disbelief when hearing achievement announcements) would be punished. Ngômo called it: facecrime, the crime shown on one's face.
tr_translation: His first thought came back; he was probably not a Thought Policeman, but he could be an amateur spy. And the greatest danger would come from them. He didn't know how long the man had been watching him; it could have been five minutes, and during that time, he was not very aware of whether he had controlled his facial expression. It was never right to let your thoughts flow freely within the view of a telescreen or in a public place. The slightest thing; a nervous tic, a sorrowful look, the habit of muttering to oneself, anything that could give the impression of abnormality or that something was being hidden could betray you. Giving your face an inappropriate expression (for example, looking bewildered when a victory was announced) was considered a punishable offense. In Newspeak, there was a word for this too; it was called facecrime.
es_translation: He thought that the girl was probably not a member of the Thought Police, but it was precisely the amateur spies who constituted the greatest danger. Winston did not know how long the young woman had been watching him, but perhaps it had been five minutes. It was very possible that during this time he had not been able to control his gestures perfectly. It was a terrible danger to think while being in a public place or within reach of the telescreen. The smallest detail could betray one. A nervous tic, an unconscious look of anxiety, the habit of talking to oneself under one's breath, anything that revealed the need to hide something. In any case, wearing an improper expression on one's face (for example, looking incredulous when a victory was announced) constituted a punishable act. There was even a word for this in Newspeak: facecrime.

en: When he had gone with that woman it had been his first lapse in two years or thereabouts. Consorting with prostitutes was forbidden, of course, but it was one of those rules that you could occasionally nerve yourself to break. It was dangerous, but it was not a life-and-death matter. To be caught with a prostitute might mean five years in a forced-labor camp: not more, if you had committed no other offense. And it was easy enough, provided that you could avoid being caught in the act. The poorer quarters swarmed with women who were ready to sell themselves. Some could even be purchased for a bottle of gin, which the proles were not supposed to drink. Tacitly the Party was even inclined to encourage prostitution, as an outlet for instincts which could not be altogether suppressed. Mere debauchery did not matter very much, so long as it was furtive and joyless, and only involved the women of a submerged and despised class. The unforgivable crime was promiscuity between Party members. But—though this was one of the crimes that the accused in the great purges invariably confessed to—it was difficult to imagine any such thing actually happening.
vi: Đây là lần sa ngã đầu tiên trong suốt hai năm qua. Dĩ nhiên là không được quan hệ với gái điếm, nhưng đôi khi cũng có thể liều. Việc này nguy hiểm đấy, nhưng không phải là vấn đề sống còn. Bị tóm tại trận thì cũng chỉ năm năm khổ sai là cùng, đấy là nói nếu không có tình tiết tăng nặng. Miễn đừng bị trai trên gái dưới là được. Các khu phố nghèo đầy bọn đàn bà sẵn sàng bán mình. Có thể chỉ một chai Gin cũng xong, bọn cu li không được uống loại rượu này. Đảng ngấm ngầm khuyến khích nạn mãi dâm vì đây là một lối thoát cho các thứ bản năng mà đằng nào cũng không đè nén được. Bản thân việc mua dâm không phải là vấn đề lớn, nhưng chỉ được quan hệ với bọn phụ nữ thuộc tầng lớp nghèo hèn, bị khinh bỉ và tất nhiên là phải lén lút. Quan hệ giữa các đảng viên là điều không thể tha thứ được. Mặc dù những người bị đàn áp trong các vụ thanh trừng lớn thường vẫn thú nhận đã phạm tội này, thật khó tưởng tượng điều đó lại có thể xảy ra trên thực tế.
tr: O kadınla gidişi, iki yıldan beri uğradığı ilk yanılgısıydı. Fahişelerle ilişki yasaktı. Ama, arasıra kendinize güveninizi toplayıp çiğneyebileceğiniz bir yasaktı bu. Bu işin tehlikeleri vardı, ama bir ölüm kalım sorunu değildi. Bir fahişeyle yakalanmak, beş yıl zorunlu çalışma kampına gönderilmek demekti. Önceden başka bir suç işlememişseniz, bütün ceza bu kadardı. Suç ânında yakalanmanın önüne geçebildiğiniz sürece oldukça kolay işlenebilir bir suçtu. Kentin yoksul kesimleri, kendilerini satmaya hazır kadınlarla kaynıyordu. Bazılarını, proleterlerin içmesi yasak olan bir şişe cine bile satın alabilirdiniz. Bütünüyle bastırılamayan bazı dürtülere bir tür kapak işlevi gördüğünden, fahişelik üstü kapalı özendiriliyordu. Gizli ve zevksiz olduğu ve küçümsenen bir sınıfın üyesi kadınlar tarafından yüklenildiği sürece, buna pek aldırış eden yoktu. Bağışlanamayan suç, Parti üyeleri arasındaki yakınlaşmalardı. Büyük temizliklerde bu, sürekli açığa vurulan suçlardan biri olmakla birlikte, böyle bir şeyin olabileceğini düşünmek bile güçtü.
es: Cuando estuvo con aquella mujer, fue la primera vez que había caído Winston en dos años aproximadamente. Por supuesto, toda relación con prostitutas estaba prohibida, pero se admitía que alguna vez, mediante un acto de gran valentía, se permitiera uno infringir la ley. Era peligroso pero no un asunto de vida o muerte, porque ser sorprendido con una prostituta sólo significaba cinco años de trabajos forzados. Nunca más de cinco años con tal de que no se hubiera cometido otro delito a la vez. Lo cual resultaba estupendo ya que había la posibilidad de que no le descubrieran a uno. Los barrios pobres abundaban en mujeres dispuestas a venderse. El precio de algunas era una botella de ginebra, bebida que se suministraba a los proles. Tácitamente, el Partido se inclinaba a estimular la prostitución como salida de los instintos que no podían suprimirse. Esas juergas no importaban políticamente ya que eran furtivas y tristes y sólo implicaban a mujeres de una clase sumergida y despreciada. El crimen imperdonable era la promiscuidad entre miembros del Partido. Pero —aunque éste era uno de los crímenes que los acusados confesaban siempre en las purgas— era casi imposible imaginar que tal desafuero pudiera suceder.
vi_translation: This is the first downfall in the past two years. Of course, engaging with prostitutes is not allowed, but sometimes one can take risks. This is dangerous, but it's not a matter of life and death. Getting caught in the act would only mean five years of hard labor at most, that is if there are no aggravating circumstances. Just don't get caught in a compromising position. The slums are full of women willing to sell themselves. Sometimes just a bottle of gin is enough, as the laborers aren't allowed to drink this kind of liquor. The Party tacitly encourages prostitution because it serves as an outlet for instincts that cannot be suppressed anyway. The act of buying sex itself is not a major issue, but it must be done with women from the poor, despised class and, of course, in secret. Relations between Party members are absolutely unforgivable. Although those oppressed in major purges often confess to this crime, it's hard to imagine it actually happening in reality.
tr_translation: His departure with that woman was the first mistake he had made in two years. Relations with prostitutes were forbidden. However, it was a rule that you could occasionally muster the confidence to break. There were dangers involved, but it was not a matter of life and death. Being caught with a prostitute meant being sent to a forced labor camp for five years. If you hadn't committed another crime before, this was the entire punishment. As long as you could avoid being caught in the act, it was a fairly easy crime to commit. The poor sections of the city were teeming with women ready to sell themselves. You could even buy some of them with a bottle of gin, which was forbidden for the proletarians to drink. Prostitution was tacitly encouraged because it served as a kind of outlet for certain urges that couldn't be completely suppressed. As long as it was secretive and unpleasurable and carried out by women from a despised class, no one really cared. The unforgivable crime was the intimacy among Party members. Although this was one of the crimes constantly exposed during the great purges, it was hard to even think that such a thing could happen.
es_translation: When he was with that woman, it was the first time Winston had fallen in about two years. Of course, any relationship with prostitutes was forbidden, but it was admitted that sometimes, through an act of great bravery, one could allow oneself to break the law. It was dangerous but not a matter of life and death, because being caught with a prostitute only meant five years of forced labor. Never more than five years as long as no other crime had been committed at the same time. Which was great since there was the possibility that one might not be discovered. The poor neighborhoods were full of women willing to sell themselves. The price for some was a bottle of gin, a drink supplied to the proles. Tacitly, the Party leaned towards encouraging prostitution as an outlet for instincts that could not be suppressed. These escapades did not matter politically since they were furtive and sad and only involved women from a submerged and despised class. The unforgivable crime was promiscuity among Party members. But —although this was one of the crimes that the accused always confessed to during the purges— it was almost impossible to imagine that such an outrage could happen.

en: When I saw her in the light she was quite an old woman, fifty years old at least. But I went ahead and did it just the same.
vi: Dưới ánh đèn mình thấy bà ta quá già, ít nhất cũng phải năm mươi. Nhưng mình vẫn làm như không có chuyện gì xảy ra.
tr: Lâmbayı açtım, onu ilk kez ışık altında gördüm, yaşlı bir kadındı. En azından ellisinde vardı. Ama umursamadım ve yapılacak işi yaptım.
es: Cuando la vi a plena luz resultó una verdadera vieja. Por lo menos tenía cincuenta años. Pero, de todos modos, lo hice.
vi_translation: Under the light, I saw that she was very old, at least fifty. But I still acted as if nothing had happened.
tr_translation: I turned on the lamp, I saw her under the light for the first time, she was an old woman. She was at least in her fifties. But I didn't care and did the job that needed to be done.
es_translation: When I saw her in full light, she turned out to be a real old woman. She was at least fifty years old. But, anyway, I did it.

en: He had gone straight on working. As soon as he saw what the photograph was, and what it meant, he had covered it up with another sheet of paper. Luckily, when he unrolled it, it had been upside-down from the point of view of the telescreen.
vi: Anh bắt đầu làm việc ngay. Anh vội lấy một tờ giấy khác đè lên bức ảnh khi vừa nhìn thấy và nhận ra ý nghĩa của nó. May là khi anh giở thì bức ảnh lại nằm ngược với hướng của màn vô tuyến.
tr: Çalışmasını sürdürmüştü. Fotoğrafı görüp anlamını kavradıktan sonra üstünü bir kâğıtla örtüvermişti. Neyse ki tomarı açtığında resim tele ekrana göre ters durmaktaydı.
es: Winston había seguido trabajando después de su descubrimiento. En cuanto vio lo que era la fotografía y lo que significaba, la cubrió con otra hoja de papel. Afortunadamente, cuando la desenrolló había quedado de tal modo que la telepantalla no podía verla.
vi_translation: He started working immediately. He hurriedly placed another sheet of paper over the photo as soon as he saw and understood its significance. Fortunately, when he turned it over, the photo was facing away from the direction of the television screen.
tr_translation: He had continued his work. After seeing the photograph and grasping its meaning, he had quickly covered it with a piece of paper. Fortunately, when he unrolled the scroll, the picture was upside down relative to the tele screen.
es_translation: Winston had continued working after his discovery. As soon as he saw what the photograph was and what it meant, he covered it with another sheet of paper. Fortunately, when he unrolled it, it had ended up in such a way that the telescreen couldn't see it.

en: But today, supposing that it could be somehow resurrected from its ashes, the photograph might not even be evidence. Already, at the time when he made his discovery, Oceania was no longer at war with Eurasia, and it must have been to the agents of Eastasia that the three dead men had betrayed their country. Since then there had been other changes—two, three, he could not remember how many. Very likely the confessions had been rewritten and rewritten until the original facts and dates no longer had the smallest significance. The past not only changed, but changed continuously. What most afflicted him with the sense of nightmare was that he had never clearly understood why the huge imposture was undertaken. The immediate advantages of falsifying the past were obvious, but the ultimate motive was mysterious. He took up his pen again and wrote:
vi: Nhưng giả sử như có thể phục hồi được bức ảnh thì có thể nó cũng không còn là bằng chứng nữa. Ngay khi anh phát hiện được bức ảnh thì Oceania đã không còn đánh nhau với Eurasia nữa và ba người kia đã phải bán nước cho điệp viên của Eastasia rồi. Từ đó đến nay còn mấy lần thay đổi nữa, hai hoặc ba lần, anh không nhớ rõ. Rất có thể là những lời thú nhận đã được viết đi viết lại nhiều lần, nhiều đến nỗi sự kiện và ngày tháng ban đầu chẳng còn một tí ý nghĩa nào nữa. Qúa khứ không chỉ bị sửa đổi mà còn bị sửa đổi thường xuyên, sửa đổi liên tục. Điều kinh khủng nhất đối với anh chính là anh không làm sao hiểu nổi tại sao lại phải làm cái công việc giả mạo hao tiền tốn của ghê gớm này. Lợi ích trước mắt thì rõ nhưng mục đích cuối cùng thì còn là bí mật. Anh cầm bút và viết:
tr: Fotoğraf, bugün küller arasından çıkarılmış olsa bile, bir kanıt sayılmayabilirdi. Daha o buluşu yapmadan önce, Okyanusya artık Avrasya ile savaşı kesmişti; o halde bu üç adam, yurtlarını Doğu Asya casuslarına satmış olacaklardı. O günden bugüne, hatırlayamadığı bir yığın suç daha yüklenmişti kendilerine. İtiraflar kuşkusuz, artık asıl tarihlerin ve gerçeklerin bir önemi kalmayıncaya kadar değişmiş ve yeniden yeniden yazılmışlardı. Geçmiş, bir kez değil, sürekli değişmekteydi. Kendisine kâbuslara neden olan şuydu: Bu korkunç düzmecenin nedeni neydi? Anlayamıyordu. Geçmişi değiştirmenin anlık yararları açıkça ortadaydı, ama son hedef gizliydi. Kalemini yeniden aldı ve şöyle yazdı:
es: Pero hoy, suponiendo que pudiera resucitar de sus cenizas, la foto no podía servir de prueba. Ya en el tiempo en que él había hecho el descubrimiento, no estaba en guerra Oceanía con Eurasia y los tres personajes suprimidos tenían que haber traicionado su país con los agentes de Asia oriental y no con los de Eurasia. Desde entonces hubo otros cambios, dos o tres, ya no podía recordarlo. Probablemente, las confesiones habían sido nuevamente escritas varias veces hasta que los hechos y las fechas originales perdieran todo significado. No es sólo que el pasado cambiara, es que cambiaba continuamente. Lo que más le producía a Winston la sensación de una pesadilla es que nunca había llegado a comprender claramente por qué se emprendía la inmensa impostura. Desde luego, eran evidentes las ventajas inmediatas de falsificar el pasado, pero la última razón era misteriosa. Volvió a coger la pluma y escribió:
vi_translation: But suppose the photograph could be recovered, it might no longer serve as evidence. By the time he discovered the photograph, Oceania was no longer at war with Eurasia, and the three men had already betrayed their country to Eastasian spies. Since then, there had been several more changes, two or three times, he couldn't remember exactly. It was very likely that the confessions had been rewritten so many times that the original events and dates no longer held any meaning. The past was not only altered but was constantly being altered, continuously revised. The most horrifying thing for him was that he couldn't understand why such an enormous and costly falsification effort was necessary. The immediate benefits were clear, but the ultimate purpose remained a secret. He picked up the pen and wrote:
tr_translation: Even if the photograph had been unearthed from the ashes today, it might not have been considered evidence. Before he made that discovery, Oceania had already ceased fighting with Eurasia; therefore, these three men must have sold their homeland to East Asian spies. Since that day, a heap of other crimes, which he could not remember, had been added to their charges. The confessions had undoubtedly been altered and rewritten over and over again until the original dates and facts no longer mattered. The past was not changing just once, but continuously. What caused him nightmares was this: What was the reason for this terrible fabrication? He could not understand. The immediate benefits of altering the past were clearly evident, but the ultimate goal was hidden. He picked up his pen again and wrote:
es_translation: But today, assuming it could rise from its ashes, the photo could not serve as proof. Even at the time when he had made the discovery, Oceania was not at war with Eurasia and the three eliminated characters had to have betrayed their country with agents of Eastasia and not with those of Eurasia. Since then there had been other changes, two or three, he could no longer remember. Probably, the confessions had been rewritten several times until the original facts and dates lost all meaning. It was not just that the past changed, it was that it changed continuously. What gave Winston the greatest sense of a nightmare was that he had never clearly understood why the immense deception was undertaken. Of course, the immediate advantages of falsifying the past were evident, but the ultimate reason was mysterious. He picked up the pen again and wrote:

en: He picked up the children’s history book and looked at the portrait of Big Brother which formed its frontispiece. The hypnotic eyes gazed into his own. It was as though some huge force were pressing down upon you—something that penetrated inside your skull, battering against your brain, frightening you out of your beliefs, persuading you, almost, to deny the evidence of your senses. In the end the Party would announce that two and two made five, and you would have to believe it. It was inevitable that they should make that claim sooner or later: the logic of their position demanded it. Not merely the validity of experience, but the very existence of external reality was tacitly denied by their philosophy. The heresy of heresies was common sense. And what was terrifying was not that they would kill you for thinking otherwise, but that they might be right. For, after all, how do we know that two and two make four? Or that the force of gravity works? Or that the past is unchangeable? If both the past and the external world exist only in the mind, and if the mind itself is controllable—what then?
vi: Anh cầm cuốn sách lịch sử dành cho thiếu nhi và ngắm bức ảnh của Anh Cả minh hoạ trên trang nhất. Cặp mắt thôi miên nhìn thẳng vào anh. Giống như có một sức mạnh vô hình đè nén người ta, xuyên thấu vỏ não, đập liên hồi kì trận vào óc, doạ dẫm buộc phải từ bỏ niềm tin của chính mình, thuyết phục người ta từ bỏ cả những giác quan của mình nữa. Cuối cùng thì Đảng có thể tuyên bố rằng hai cộng hai là năm và dân chúng sẽ buộc phải tin. Sớm muộn gì họ sẽ tuyên bố như thế, quyền lực của họ đòi hỏi như vậy. Triết lí của họ không chỉ ngấm ngầm phủ nhận giá trị của kinh nghiệm mà còn phủ nhận luôn cả hiện thực khách quan nữa. Điều nhảm nhí nhất trong những điều nhảm nhí đã trở thành hợp lí. Sợ nhất không phải là họ sẽ giết vì ta nghĩ khác mà là họ có thể đúng. Thực ra làm sao ta biết được rằng hai cộng với hai là bốn? Hoặc làm sao ta biết có lực hấp dẫn? Làm sao ta biết là quá khứ không thể thay đổI được? Hoặc giả nếu quá khứ và thế giới bên ngoài chỉ tồn tại trong tâm mà tâm có thể điều khiển được thì sao?
tr: Çocuklar için yazılmış tarih kitabını aldı. Büyük Biraderin kapaktaki resmine baktı. İnsanı donduran o gözlere baktı. Büyük bir kuvvet üzerinize basınç uyguluyordu sanki; kafatasınızı delip beyninize balyozla vuruyor, inançlarınızı söküp alıyor, sizi beş duyunuza bile inanmamaya zorluyordu. Sonunda, Parti iki kere ikinin beş ettiğini duyuracak ve insan da buna inanmak zorunda kalacaktı. Bu sav eninde sonunda öne sürülecekti, durumlarının mantığı bunu gerektiriyordu. Yalnızca deneyimlerin geçerliliği değil, dış gerçeklerin varlığı bile düşünce sistemle-rince yadsınıyordu. Gerçeğe karşı çıkan öğretilere karşı çıkmanın tek yolu sağduyudan ayrılmamaktı. İnsanı ürküten, başka türlü düşündüğü için öldürülmek değil, onların haklı olabilecekleri olasılığıydı. İki kere ikinin dört ettiğini nereden biliyorduk? Ya da yerçekimi yasasının geçerliliğini? Ya da geçmişin değiştirilemez olduğunu? Eğer geçmiş ve dış dünya yalnızca beynimizde var oluyorsa ve beynin kendisi de denetlenebiliyorsa... Öyleyse bu araştırmanın yararı neydi?
es: Cogió el libro de texto infantil y miró el retrato del Gran Hermano que llenaba la portada. Los ojos hipnóticos se clavaron en los suyos. Era como si una inmensa fuerza empezara a aplastarle a uno, algo que iba penetrando en el cráneo, golpeaba el cerebro por dentro, le aterrorizaba a uno y llegaba casi a persuadirle que era de noche cuando era de día. Al final, el Partido anunciaría que dos y dos son cinco y habría que creerlo. Era inevitable que llegara algún día al dos y dos son cinco. La lógica de su posición lo exigía. Su filosofía negaba no sólo la validez de la experiencia, sino que existiera la realidad externa. La mayor de las herejías era el sentido común. Y lo más terrible no era que le mataran a uno por pensar de otro modo, sino que pudieran tener razón. Porque, después de todo, ¿cómo sabemos que dos y dos son efectivamente cuatro? O que la fuerza de la gravedad existe. O que el pasado no puede ser alterado. ¿Y si el pasado y el mundo exterior sólo existen en nuestra mente y, siendo la mente controlable, también puede controlarse el pasado y lo que llamamos la realidad?
vi_translation: He held a children's history book and gazed at the picture of Big Brother illustrated on the first page. The hypnotic eyes stared straight at him. It was as if an invisible force was pressing down on him, penetrating his cortex, pounding incessantly on his brain, threatening to force him to abandon his own beliefs, persuading him to even abandon his own senses. In the end, the Party could declare that two plus two equals five and the people would be forced to believe it. Sooner or later they would declare it, their power demanded it. Their philosophy not only implicitly denied the value of experience but also denied objective reality itself. The most nonsensical of nonsense had become reasonable. The scariest thing was not that they would kill you for thinking differently but that they might be right. How do we really know that two plus two is four? Or how do we know there is gravity? How do we know that the past cannot be changed? Or what if the past and the outside world only exist in the mind and the mind can be controlled?
tr_translation: He took the history book written for children. He looked at the picture of Big Brother on the cover. He looked into those chilling eyes. It was as if a great force was applying pressure on you; drilling into your skull and hammering your brain, ripping out your beliefs, forcing you not to believe even in your five senses. In the end, the Party would announce that two plus two equals five, and people would have to believe it. This claim would eventually be put forward; the logic of their situation required it. Not only the validity of experiences but even the existence of external realities was denied by their thought systems. The only way to oppose doctrines that opposed reality was not to part from common sense. What was frightening was not being killed for thinking differently, but the possibility that they might be right. How did we know that two plus two equals four? Or the validity of the law of gravity? Or that the past could not be altered? If the past and the external world only existed in our minds and the mind itself could be controlled...Then what was the use of this investigation?
es_translation: He took the children's textbook and looked at the portrait of Big Brother that filled the cover. The hypnotic eyes locked onto his. It was as if an immense force began to crush him, something that penetrated his skull, pounded his brain from within, terrified him, and almost persuaded him that it was night when it was day. In the end, the Party would announce that two and two make five and it would have to be believed. It was inevitable that one day it would come to two and two make five. The logic of their position demanded it. Their philosophy denied not only the validity of experience but also the existence of external reality. The greatest heresy was common sense. And the most terrible thing was not that one would be killed for thinking differently, but that they might be right. Because, after all, how do we know that two and two are indeed four? Or that the force of gravity exists. Or that the past cannot be altered. What if the past and the external world only exist in our minds and, since the mind is controllable, the past and what we call reality can also be controlled?

en: He walked on. The bomb had demolished a group of houses two hundred meters up the street. A black plume of smoke hung in the sky, and below it a cloud of plaster dust in which a crowd was already forming round the ruins. There was a little pile of plaster lying on the pavement ahead of him, and in the middle of it he could see a bright red streak. When he got up to it he saw that it was a human hand severed at the wrist. Apart from the bloody stump, the hand was so completely whitened as to resemble a plaster cast.
vi: Anh tiếp tục đi. Quả tên lửa phá sập mấy căn nhà cách đó chừng hai trăm mét. Một đám khói đen treo lơ lửng trên bầu trời, phía bên dưới, đám đông đã tụ lại xung quanh những đống gạch vụn còn mù mịt bụi vữa. Anh nhìn thấy trong đống xà bần nằm trên vỉa hè cách chỗ anh đứng mấy mét một vệt màu đỏ. Khi đến gần thì nhận ra đó là một bàn tay người. Trừ chỗ cổ tay dính máu ra, cả bàn tay trông trắng bệch như đúc bằng thạch cao.
tr: Yürümeyi sürdürdü. Bomba caddenin iki yüz metre ötesindeki bir dizi evi yerle bir etmişti. Siyah bir duman bulutu havada asılı duruyordu, onun altında, havayı dolduran sıva tozlarının içinde bir kalabalık oluşmaya başlamıştı bile. İlende, üzerinde kırmızı bir leke bulunan küçük bir sıva yığını kaldırımı örtmekteydi. İyice yaklaştığı zaman, lekenin bileğinden kopmuş bir el olduğunu fark etti. Kanlı bilek dışında, el, alçıdan dökülmüş gibi bembeyazdı.
es: Siguió andando. La bomba había destruido un grupo de casas de aquella calle doscientos metros más arriba. En el cielo flotaba una negra nube de humo y debajo otra nube, ésta de polvo, envolvía las ruinas en torno a las cuales se agolpaba ya una multitud. Había un pequeño montón de yeso en el pavimento delante de él y en medio se podía ver una brillante raya roja. Cuando se levantó y se acercó a ver qué era vio que se trataba de una mano humana cortada por la muñeca. Aparte del sangriento muñón, la mano era tan blanca que parecía un molde de yeso.
vi_translation: He continued walking. The rocket destroyed several houses about two hundred meters away. A black cloud of smoke hung in the sky, and below it, a crowd had gathered around the piles of rubble still shrouded in dust. He saw a red streak in the debris lying on the sidewalk a few meters from where he stood. When he got closer, he realized it was a human hand. Except for the blood-stained wrist, the entire hand looked pale as if it were cast in plaster.
tr_translation: He continued walking. The bomb had leveled a row of houses two hundred meters down the street. A black cloud of smoke hung in the air, and beneath it, a crowd had already begun to form in the plaster dust that filled the air. Further ahead, a small pile of plaster with a red stain on it was covering the sidewalk. When he got closer, he realized that the stain was a hand severed at the wrist. Apart from the bloody wrist, the hand was as white as if it had been cast in plaster.
es_translation: He continued walking. The bomb had destroyed a group of houses on that street two hundred meters further up. A black cloud of smoke floated in the sky, and below another cloud, this one of dust, enveloped the ruins around which a crowd was already gathering. There was a small pile of plaster on the pavement in front of him, and in the middle of it, a bright red streak could be seen. When he got up and approached to see what it was, he saw that it was a human hand cut off at the wrist. Apart from the bloody stump, the hand was so white it looked like a plaster mold.

en: “No, it ’as not! Back ’ome I got the ’ole lot of ’em for over two years wrote down on a piece of paper. I takes ’em down reg’lar as the clock. An’ I tell you, no number ending in seven—”
vi: “Tao bảo không! Ở nhà tao có ghi ra giấy suốt hai năm qua. Tao ghi đều như đồng hồ ấy chứ. Tao bảo mày đít bảy chưa ăn lần nào.”
tr: "Hayır, kazanamadı!.. İki yıldır evde bütün sonuçları biriktiriyorum. Hepsini düzenli sayıyorum. Onun için dinle beni, yediyle biten hiçbir şey kazanmadı!
es: —No, no ha salido ninguno terminado en siete. En casa los tengo apuntados todos en un papel desde hace dos años. Nunca dejo de copiar el número. Y te digo que ningún número ha terminado en siete...
vi_translation: "I told you no! At home, I've been writing it down on paper for the past two years. I've been recording it regularly like clockwork. I told you, you haven't eaten seven yet."
tr_translation: "No, it didn't win!.. I've been collecting all the results at home for two years. I'm counting them all regularly. So listen to me, nothing ending in seven has won!"
es_translation: —No, none ending in seven has come out. At home, I have them all written down on a piece of paper for the past two years. I never fail to copy the number. And I'm telling you, no number has ended in seven...

en: “I arst you civil enough, didn’t I?” said the old man, straightening his shoulders pugnaciously. “You telling me you ain’t got a pint mug in the ’ole bleeding boozer?”
vi: “Tôi chỉ xin anh thôi”, ông lão vừa nói vừa vươn vai lên có vẻ muốn gây sự. “Thế mà anh lại bảo tôi rằng quán của anh không bán theo pint.
tr: "Sana adam gibi sorduk, değil mi?" dedi yaşlı adam omuzlarını dikleştirerek, "Bana bir payntlık bardağın olmadığını söylüyorsun, öyle mi?
es: —¿Vas a decirme que no puedes servirme una pinta de cerveza? decía el viejo.
vi_translation: "I just beg you," the old man said while stretching as if he wanted to cause trouble. "And yet you tell me that your shop doesn't sell by the pint."
tr_translation: "We asked you nicely, didn't we?" said the old man, straightening his shoulders, "You're telling me you don't have a pint glass, is that so?"
es_translation: —Are you going to tell me that you can't serve me a pint of beer? said the old man. —— And what the devil of a name is that, "pinta"?

en: “’Ark at ’im! Calls ’isself a barman and don’t know what a pint is! Why, a pint’s the ’alf of a quart, and there’s four quarts to the gallon. ’Ave to teach you the A, B, C next.”
vi: “Các vị có nghe rõ không? Chủ quán mà không biết pint là gì! Pint là nửa quart [1] , bốn quart là một gallon [2] . Chả lẽ phải dạy anh từ A, B, C nữa sao?”
tr: "Vay cahil! Bir de kendini barmen sanıyor. Payntın ne demek olduğunu bile bilmiyor! Paynt bir çeyreğin yarısıdır ve bir galonda dön çeyrek vardır. Sana A, B, C'yi de öğretmem gerekecek.
es: —— ¿Y qué demonios de nombre es ese de «pinta»? —preguntó el tabernero inclinándose sobre el mostrador con los dedos apoyados en él. —Escuchad, presume de tabernero y no sabe lo que es una pinta. A éste hay que mandarle a la escuela.
vi_translation: "Did you all hear that clearly? The innkeeper doesn't even know what a pint is! A pint is half a quart [1], and four quarts make a gallon [2]. Do I really have to teach you from A, B, C again?"
tr_translation: "Oh, you fool! You even think you're a bartender. You don't even know what a pint is! A pint is half of a quart and there are four quarts in a gallon. I'll have to teach you the ABCs as well."
es_translation: —asked the bartender, leaning over the counter with his fingers resting on it. —Listen, he boasts of being a bartender and doesn't know what a pint is. This one needs to be sent to school.

en: The old man’s pale blue eyes moved from the darts board to the bar, and from the bar to the door of the Gents, as though it were in the barroom that he expected the changes to have occurred.
vi: Đôi mắt xanh đã mờ đục vì năm tháng chuyển từ bàn chơi phi tiêu sang quầy rượu rồi cánh cửa nhà vệ sinh làm như có thể tìm được những thay đổi ấy ngay tại đây, trong quán bar này không bằng.
tr: İhtiyar adamın solgun mavi gözleri ok tablasından bara, bardan tuvalete çevrildi, sanki değişiklik olması gereken yer o meyhaneymiş gibi...
es: La pálida mirada azul del viejo recorrió el local como si fuera allí donde los cambios habían ocurrido.
vi_translation: The blue eyes had grown dim over the years, moving from the dartboard to the bar counter and then to the restroom door, as if one could find those changes right here, in this very bar.
tr_translation: The old man's pale blue eyes shifted from the dartboard to the bar, from the bar to the restroom, as if the place where change should happen was that tavern...
es_translation: The old man's pale blue gaze swept across the place as if it were there that the changes had occurred.

en: “It’s all wars,” said the old man vaguely. He took up his glass, and his shoulders straightened again. “’Ere’s wishing you the very best of ’ealth!”
vi: “Chiến tranh liên miên”, lão già giải thích. Lão nâng vại bia lên, ngực ưỡn ra theo thói quen. CChúc sức khoẻ anh!”
tr: "Büyük savaştan," dedi adam belli belirsiz. Bardağını kaldırdı, tekrar omuzlarını dikleştirdi, "Sağlığına!" dedi.
es: —Siempre hay alguna guerra —dijo el anciano con vaguedad. Levantó el vaso y brindó—: ¡A su salud, caballero!
vi_translation: "Continuous wars," the old man explained. The old man lifted his beer mug, his chest puffing out habitually. "Cheers to your health!"
tr_translation: "From the great war," the man said faintly. He lifted his glass, straightened his shoulders again, "To your health!" he said.
es_translation: —There is always some war —said the old man vaguely. He raised the glass and toasted—: To your health, sir!

en: “One of ’em pushed me once,” said the old man. “I recollect it as if it was yesterday.
